item.title: RT by @fede_intern: DeepSeek R1 is no AI Sputnik moment. It shows the power of open-source technology over proprietary. This is all of crypto. A breakdown of global boundaries in technological innovation.
item.dc:creator: @benafisch
item.description: DeepSeek R1 is no AI Sputnik moment. It shows the power of open-source technology over proprietary. This is all of crypto. A breakdown of global boundaries in technological innovation.

item.title: RT by @fede_intern: Recall that one of the stated reasons OpenAI chose to hide o1‚Äôs reasoning was for safety. Keep this in mind as absolutely zero harm comes from seeing DeepSeek-R1‚Äôs reasoning.

item.description: Recall that one of the stated reasons OpenAI chose to hide o1‚Äôs reasoning was for safety. Keep this in mind as absolutely zero harm comes from seeing DeepSeek-R1‚Äôs reasoning.

item.title: It's 4 AM a Sunday and we're trolling DeepSeek:
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description: It's 4 AM a Sunday and we're trolling DeepSeek:

item.title: RT by @fede_intern: Modularity forces innovation. L2s compete, build, and improve Ethereum‚Äîwithout breaking the L1. That‚Äôs the superpower.
item.dc:creator: @benafisch
item.description: Modularity forces innovation. L2s compete, build, and improve Ethereum‚Äîwithout breaking the L1. That‚Äôs the superpower.

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: @VitalikButerin 's recent blog reinforces key themes I‚Äôve been discussing: Ethereum‚Äôs strength is in its entire ecosystem‚ÄîL1, L2s, and adjacent infra.
Ethereum isn‚Äôt just a tech stack‚Äîit‚Äôs a decentralized social system driving innovation.
item.dc:creator: @benafisch
item.description:
@VitalikButerin 's recent blog reinforces key themes I‚Äôve been discussing: Ethereum‚Äôs strength is in its entire ecosystem‚ÄîL1, L2s, and adjacent infra.

Ethereum isn‚Äôt just a tech stack‚Äîit‚Äôs a decentralized social system driving innovation.

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: Beginning with ERC-20s, Ethereum became a platform where developers could innovate sustainably, aligning their interests with the network‚Äôs growth.
This isn‚Äôt just a technical feature‚Äîit‚Äôs a core philosophical advantage that has made Ethereum the most vibrant ecosystem in Web3.
item.dc:creator: @benafisch
item.description:
Beginning with ERC-20s, Ethereum became a platform where developers could innovate sustainably, aligning their interests with the network‚Äôs growth.

This isn‚Äôt just a technical feature‚Äîit‚Äôs a core philosophical advantage that has made Ethereum the most vibrant ecosystem in Web3.

item.title: RT by @fede_intern: But there's something powerful about having a core L1 that is stable, reliable, and secure‚Äîone that doesn‚Äôt move fast and break things. Bitcoin is the ultimate example of conservatism. Ethereum found a middle ground compared to more recent L1s (e.g. from the 2017 era).
item.dc:creator: @benafisch
item.description: But there's something powerful about having a core L1 that is stable, reliable, and secure‚Äîone that doesn‚Äôt move fast and break things. Bitcoin is the ultimate example of conservatism. Ethereum found a middle ground compared to more recent L1s (e.g. from the 2017 era).

item.title: RT by @fede_intern: Slow development on the L1 gave rise to an enormous developer community, all building experimental infrastructure complementary to the L1. This is an advantage not a crutch.
item.dc:creator: @benafisch
item.description: Slow development on the L1 gave rise to an enormous developer community, all building experimental infrastructure complementary to the L1. This is an advantage not a crutch.

item.title:
Example of criticism I have to our own tech: our current p2p ethrex code is a piece of shit. It needs to be re written. I‚Äôm calling @mpaulucci_ every day to fix this asap.
I‚Äôm always like this, that‚Äôs how we improve.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
Example of criticism I have to our own tech: our current p2p ethrex code is a piece of shit. It needs to be re written. I‚Äôm calling @mpaulucci_ every day to fix this asap.

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: This is delusional. ‚Äúthe appropriate forums‚Äù, the incapacity of accepting a simple mistake is surprising to me. I think this this shows how you work with criticism.
Every big company shows their mistakes publicly and even writes blog posts about them. You didn‚Äôt even generated a CVE for each bug.
With this last message I‚Äôve changed my mind. I do believe you‚Äôre trying to just move forward and not care much about it. Next time I will make sure things are more clear and public. You just generated incentives for that.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: ¬´ [saying] user funds were not at risk because the prover is permissioned shows me that we live in two very different worlds ¬ª
This should *never* be a satisfying answer. Wherever there are bugs, there‚Äôs someone to exploit them. 100% aligned with Fede here. Fix bugs. Period.

item.title: I've criticized half of my clients publicly and also Lambda. Let's accept honest debates rather than just shilling.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
I've criticized half of my clients publicly and also Lambda. Let's accept honest debates rather than just shilling.

nitter.freedit.eu/fede_intern/status/1883689064563613967#m

item.title:
A few months ago the author of revm told me that we copied some code from him. I didn't know, my tech managers didn't know. I publicly acknowledged it. I said sorry and I sent a message in slack to the people involved saying you are fired. 5 minutes afterwards they were out of of the office. Please don't tell me that I'm just criticizing you for some strange reason. I can assure you if we had a security bug I would be tweeting about it like "THANK GOD this was found by an honest party". Anybody that knows me knows that I would be doing that. I can be autistic but when I have a fight with somebody I make it super public. I'm not gonna use different standards with another party just because it's another party.
Ask any employee or partner. I'm way more aggressive and harsh with any internal mistake than external ones.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:

Please don't tell me that I'm just criticizing you for some strange reason. I can assure you if we had a security bug I would be tweeting about it like "THANK GOD this was found by an honest party". Anybody that knows me knows that I would be doing that. I can be autistic but when I have a fight with somebody I make it super public. I'm not gonna use different standards with another party just because it's another party.

Ask any employee or partner. I'm way more aggressive and harsh with any internal mistake than external ones.

item.title:
What this shows me is that some people in crypto don't like transparent public debates.
The problem with open source in crypto is that it's full of bullshit since you pledge alliance to short term incentives created by crypto VCs.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:

item.title: R to @fede_intern: zcash disclosure: https://electriccoin.co/blog/zcash-counterfeiting-vulnerability-successfully-remediated/
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description: zcash disclosure: electriccoin.co/blog/zcash-c‚Ä¶

item.title:
So this is how the history goes:
1. We found two security bugs in @SuccinctLabs SP1 with @3miLabs @alignedlayer and @class_lambda. If you combine the two bugs you can create a soundness exploit and prove any arbitrary program. For example you can prove you have the private keys of somebody else. TLDR: proving-verifying is fully broken.
2. Succinct never posted in a blogpost, they never posted in X. We waited for 40 days.
3. I just publicly criticize them for not showing publicly the bug. I also said they managed all the rest very professionally.
4. The answer I get from John and Uma is that I am doing a criticism to them that I would not do to somebody else and that X is not the place to post security disclosures. This is a strawman argument. You can post it in a blogpost as almost any company does. What you did is you just avoided talking about a very relevant bug in the security product you're building.
5. My concrete criticism consists in: a) Creating a github issue mixed with another bug is not the proper way to share a soundness bug with the community. If we were smaller less known company, people wouldn't even know that the bug exists. It's a relevant bug. In your position I would have released a blog post and written a thread in X. By putting the fix in a new version and not speaking publicly about it you're almost just discarding it.
b) The fact that your answered privately that user funds were not at risk because the prover is permissioned shows me that we live in two very different worlds. What happens if a developer is using your tech and you don't know about it in a permissionless way? What happens if somebody uses another exploit to hack the prover? We used two bugs to prove what we wanted, what makes another company not be able to use the two that were reported + another 0 day? The core idea of ZK is that you only need to trust the verifier/math.
a) and b) show me that ZK is not yet ready for massive usage yet. We can't still accept relevant problems. I hope we can learn before we have hackers stealing funds from common people.
Everyone has security bugs. We're not better than you. The difference is that we would have accepted it very publicly and I would be sharing it publicly. There is nothing bad with it. Exactly as @zcash did with their inflation bug. Check next tweet.
I didn't have anything against you guys but I don't think any of this is serious. Particularly the way you handle a simple critic.
At last, you need to still fix the second bug. You have only fixed the first bug in 40 days.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
So this is how the history goes:

1. We found two security bugs in @SuccinctLabs SP1 with @3miLabs @alignedlayer and @class_lambda. If you combine the two bugs you can create a soundness exploit and prove any arbitrary program. For example you can prove you have the private keys of somebody else. TLDR: proving-verifying is fully broken.

2. Succinct never posted in a blogpost, they never posted in X. We waited for 40 days.

3. I just publicly criticize them for not showing publicly the bug. I also said they managed all the rest very professionally.

4. The answer I get from John and Uma is that I am doing a criticism to them that I would not do to somebody else and that X is not the place to post security disclosures. This is a strawman argument. You can post it in a blogpost as almost any company does. What you did is you just avoided talking about a very relevant bug in the security product you're building.

5. My concrete criticism consists in:
a) Creating a github issue mixed with another bug is not the proper way to share a soundness bug with the community. If we were smaller less known company, people wouldn't even know that the bug exists. It's a relevant bug. In your position I would have released a blog post and written a thread in X. By putting the fix in a new version and not speaking publicly about it you're almost just discarding it.

b) The fact that your answered privately that user funds were not at risk because the prover is permissioned shows me that we live in two very different worlds. What happens if a developer is using your tech and you don't know about it in a permissionless way? What happens if somebody uses another exploit to hack the prover? We used two bugs to prove what we wanted, what makes another company not be able to use the two that were reported + another 0 day? The core idea of ZK is that you only need to trust the verifier/math.

a) and b) show me that ZK is not yet ready for massive usage yet. We can't still accept relevant problems. I hope we can learn before we have hackers stealing funds from common people.

Everyone has security bugs. We're not better than you. The difference is that we would have accepted it very publicly and I would be sharing it publicly. There is nothing bad with it. Exactly as @zcash did with their inflation bug. Check next tweet.

I didn't have anything against you guys but I don't think any of this is serious. Particularly the way you handle a simple critic.

At last, you need to still fix the second bug. You have only fixed the first bug in 40 days.

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng:
>> Studies machine vision at Zhejiang University
>> At 30 in 2015, launches High-Flyer quant hedge fund
>> Makes a fortune (now $8B AUM)
>> Wants to build ‚Äúhuman‚Äù level AI as side hustle and pitches partners but they initially sceptical
>> Buys 10,000 H800 chips in 2021 and brings over his top hedge fund employees (all have tons of experience squeezing juice out of Nvidia GPUs for the fund)
>> Launched DeepSeek in 2023 and hires dozens of PhDs from top Chinese universities (Peking, Tsinghua and Beihang)
>> Pays top top top salary for tech talent only matched by Bytedance in China‚Ä¶wants DeepSeek to be leading ‚Äúlocal‚Äù company
>> US export restrictions force DeepSeek team to get creative and they do, finding new training methods to make LLM models (V3, r1) competitive with OpenAI, Anthropic, Gemini, Grok, LLama etc at ~1/20th the cost
>> Training costs not exactly apples-to-apples but novel methods and clear improvements in efficiency (also questions around copying other models, larger H-100 clusters they maybe can‚Äôt talk about and/or CCP support)
>> Open sources and publishes methods (r1 reasoning paper has 200+ authors)
>> DeepSeek just hit top of App Store
***
FT: https://www.ft.com/content/747a7b11-dcba-4aa5-8d25-403f56216d7e
item.dc:creator: @TrungTPhan
item.description:
DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng:

>> Studies machine vision at Zhejiang University

>> At 30 in 2015, launches High-Flyer quant hedge fund

>> Makes a fortune (now $8B AUM)

>> Wants to build ‚Äúhuman‚Äù level AI as side hustle and pitches partners but they initially sceptical

>> Buys 10,000 H800 chips in 2021 and brings over his top hedge fund employees (all have tons of experience squeezing juice out of Nvidia GPUs for the fund)

>> Launched DeepSeek in 2023 and hires dozens of PhDs from top Chinese universities (Peking, Tsinghua and Beihang)

>> Pays top top top salary for tech talent only matched by Bytedance in China‚Ä¶wants DeepSeek to be leading ‚Äúlocal‚Äù company

>> US export restrictions force DeepSeek team to get creative and they do, finding new training methods to make LLM models (V3, r1) competitive with OpenAI, Anthropic, Gemini, Grok, LLama etc at ~1/20th the cost

>> Training costs not exactly apples-to-apples but novel methods and clear improvements in efficiency (also questions around copying other models, larger H-100 clusters they maybe can‚Äôt talk about and/or CCP support)

>> Open sources and publishes methods (r1 reasoning paper has 200+ authors)

>> DeepSeek just hit top of App Store

***

FT: ft.com/content/747a7b11-dcba‚Ä¶

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: I can now confirm that yes, you have AGI at home w/ Deepseek R1.
Running locally on CPU and RAM with llama.cpp after much trial, getting apx 3.4 tokens/sec.
item.dc:creator: @Sentdex
item.description:
I can now confirm that yes, you have AGI at home w/ Deepseek R1.

Running locally on CPU and RAM with llama.cpp after much trial, getting apx 3.4 tokens/sec.
